news_insight_text_link.news_insight_description: Cylib, a German-based startup focusing on sustainable battery recycling, has successfully raised €55 million in a Series A funding round. The investment was led by European climate tech VC World Fund and Porsche Ventures, aiming to scale its next-gen lithium-ion battery recycling technology.

org_similarity_summary.insight_similar_orgs: Cylib, Healix Clean Tech, and Octillion Power Systems operate in the clean-tech and sustainable energy sector. Cylib focuses on holistic battery recycling, while Healix Clean Tech aims to solve the plastic problem. Octillion Power Systems provides advanced lithium-ion batteries for industrial and vehicle applications.

overview_description.description: Greentech startup cylib is on a mission to revolutionize how lithium-ion batteries are recycled in Europe, making the process more efficient and sustainable.

about_short_description.short_description: Cylib is a start-up for holistic battery recycling

product.name: End-to-End Battery Recycling Process
product.description: Cylib's proprietary technology recycles lithium-ion batteries, recovering all valuable materials including lithium, cobalt, and graphite, aiming for a circular economy.

product.name: Water-Based Lithium and Graphite Recovery
product.description: Innovative process that recovers lithium and graphite from batteries using a water-based method, reducing the need for harmful chemicals.

product.name: Base Metal Recovery
product.description: Thermal, mechanical, and hydrometallurgical steps enable the recovery of base metals like cobalt, as well as the separation of aluminum and copper foils.

product.name: Clean Hydrometallurgy
product.description: A process developed to reduce the use of additives and acids in the recovery of graphite and lithium, making it more environmentally friendly.

product.name: From Waste to Resources
product.description: Transforms waste from end-of-life batteries or production scrap into marketable products, covering all steps from discharging to hydrometallurgical extraction.
